codes.name: AI Applications in Research Workflow
codes.description: This code encompasses the various ways Artificial Intelligence tools are being used or could be used across different stages of the research process, from data collection to analysis and dissemination.
codes.semantic_definition: The practical and potential utility of AI technologies to enhance efficiency, scope, and capabilities within the research lifecycle.
example_quotes: I have used AI tools to help with my code. I know in general how to execute one of these methods but sometime there are new packages written but my code is having errors so I can take the code and put it in an LLM; can you fix this error or can you write this more concisely?
I’ve also done things for proposal writing and taken my idea where I want to use a particular design and poke holes in this; What are the problems with this; how can I strengthen this?

We did write a python script to use the RAND CHAT to review a bunch of papers. So we did the literature review and had it spit out in a spreadsheet a once sentence summary of the paper or we asked it questions, is this paper based in the US?

Like Can you imagine? A world where, like AI could feed in information about the kind of participants you're looking for. And AI could crawl the Internet to find them. Invite them to participate and then find a time on your calendar for the interview.

codes.name: Data Collection & Management
codes.description: The use of AI to assist with identifying and recruiting research participants, managing data collection processes, and preparing data for analysis.
codes.semantic_definition: AI's role in streamlining the acquisition, organization, and initial preparation of research data, including participant recruitment and data cleaning.
example_quotes: Finding the right people and recruiting them.

Like Can you imagine? A world where, like AI could feed in information about the kind of participants you're looking for. And AI could crawl the Internet to find them. Invite them to participate and then find a time on your calendar for the interview.

Even just inputting all of Rand's past projects and who their partners are and like what they did, and having an AI crawl through all of that like, I feel like there's a lot of good leads that like across Rand.

The time-consuming process of pulling data down, checking code. So one thing when I feed it in and there is an error, but then you can use the ai tools to check the code, annotate the code, replicability those are time consuming and for AI.

codes.name: Qualitative Data Analysis
codes.description: The application of AI tools for tasks related to the analysis of qualitative data, such as transcription, summarization, thematic coding, and extracting quantitative insights from qualitative content.
codes.semantic_definition: AI's function in processing, interpreting, and structuring unstructured qualitative data to identify patterns, themes, and frequencies.
example_quotes: I've been using some of the LLM's for. And kind of more exploring some of their. Thematic coding and kind of ability to kind of group documents then generate text for me...
Coding large amounts of data. Coding Is very annoying.
So tabulating, tabulating the frequency of of of comments and topics.
Otter? That tool is used for research. Providers and patients and they are using Otter to take notes and it transcribes and summarizes.

codes.name: Literature & Information Synthesis
codes.description: The use of AI to assist with conducting literature reviews, environmental scans, and synthesizing information from large bodies of text, including identifying relevant sources and extracting key details.
codes.semantic_definition: AI's role in automating and enhancing the process of discovering, reviewing, and consolidating existing knowledge from diverse textual sources.
example_quotes: We did try to like use one of those, like elicit. I think it was called to see like whether it was. As accurate as our Ra's. But it got like expensive quickly and we when we looked at the side by side comparison between what RA’s extracted and what Elicit did, there were some inconsistencies, I think.

I always have to rely on the librarian for. It's like all of the search strategy stuff like 'cause like they know all of the typologies of how language works in all of the different databases, and so what are the right search terms depending on what you're looking for and when to use the “and” and “or” and like. All of that, the search architecture. Feels like there's, like, you know, probably an AI solution to that...

I think the RAND CHAT one is not as good, a couple of times I would ask RAND CHAT, are there systematic studies on blah or what do you know about x and y and it would give me papers/citations that were not real. So I always check.
The main reason we did that was because the client a federal agency wanted us to do this massive literature review in one month.

codes.name: Research Design & Communication
codes.description: The application of AI to support the conceptualization of research designs, the development of proposals, and the clear communication of research findings.
codes.semantic_definition: AI's function in aiding the ideation, structuring, and articulation of research projects and their outputs, including proposal writing, simplifying complex information, and tailoring language.
example_quotes: I’ve also done things for proposal writing and taken my idea where I want to use a particular design and poke holes in this; What are the problems with this; how can I strengthen this?
I take the whole proposal and say write an executive summary; it is great at doing that; you can’t trust it but sometimes stuff that is off and misses nuance but it is pretty good at that.

So I take the text and say explain like I’m five. The other thing I’ve done; I’ve taken text and said which of the sentences in here will upset some opposed to DEI and it will flag sentences and makes me look at it again.
Somewhere you can say, I want something that looks like an experiment but relevant to labor markets.

codes.name: Challenges and Risks of AI in Research
codes.description: This code captures the difficulties, limitations, and potential negative consequences associated with the adoption and use of AI in qualitative research.
codes.semantic_definition: The inherent obstacles, inaccuracies, ethical dilemmas, and broader societal concerns that arise from integrating AI into research methodologies.
example_quotes: But I was finding that it was it was difficult for me to like a just inherently trust what it was spitting out in a way that maybe you want to just like take it and use it to draw further conclusions.
We found when you know going back and rereading it, that there were definitely, like, nuances that were missed and things that, you know were not picked up that were relevant to our project.

I don't want to inadvertently take someone else's intellectual property. Saw a thing on john Oliver, ppl making images, based on what is in the public and making something new so it is kind of stealing.

As AI continues to create more content. And it like feeds itself and and it's basing that content on some right stuff and some wrong stuff. So it's perpetuating some wrong stuff and it just keeps getting bigger and bigger like it gets it just. It's like feeding itself.

codes.name: Accuracy & Reliability Concerns
codes.description: Issues related to the precision, consistency, and trustworthiness of AI-generated outputs, including missed nuances, inconsistencies, and fabricated information.
codes.semantic_definition: The problems of AI producing incorrect, incomplete, or misleading data, requiring human verification and validation.
example_quotes: But I was finding that it was it was difficult for me to like a just inherently trust what it was spitting out in a way that maybe you want to just like take it and use it to draw further conclusions.
We found when you know going back and rereading it, that there were definitely, like, nuances that were missed and things that, you know were not picked up that were relevant to our project.

I think the RAND CHAT one is not as good, a couple of times I would ask RAND CHAT, are there systematic studies on blah or what do you know about x and y and it would give me papers/citations that were not real. So I always check.
I asked an LLM for something and explicitly asked to NOT make up references, and it still made up a reference. so i need to really see good evidence that i can trust it before using for lit reviews

codes.name: Ethical & Societal Implications
codes.description: Broader concerns about the impact of AI on intellectual property, the nature of competition, and the potential for AI systems to perpetuate or amplify misinformation.
codes.semantic_definition: The moral, legal, and systemic challenges posed by AI's integration into society and research, including issues of ownership, fairness, and the integrity of information ecosystems.
example_quotes: I don’t want to inadvertently take someone else’s intellectual property. Saw a thing on john Oliver, ppl making images, based on what is in the public and making something new so it is kind of stealing.

I think somebody actually people aren't anticipating about AI development is some of this technology will be like a red Queen scenario. So you're just running faster and faster. So in the red Queen's running faster and faster to stay in the same place like on a treadmill.

As AI continues to create more content. And it like feeds itself and and it's basing that content on some right stuff and some wrong stuff. So it's perpetuating some wrong stuff and it just keeps getting bigger and bigger like it gets it just. It's like feeding itself.
I just have lots of opinions about its potential negative impacts on humans and society

codes.name: Limitations of AI Autonomy
codes.description: The inherent boundaries of AI's ability to perform complex, nuanced, or context-dependent tasks without significant human oversight or intervention.
codes.semantic_definition: The areas where AI cannot fully replace human judgment, contextual understanding, or the "intimacy with data" required for rigorous qualitative research.
example_quotes: I mean, there's, I I hear you. There's definitely something to be said about the intimacy 1 gets with the data.

AI can't replace us in reading transcripts and understanding the context behind the interview in understanding the conversation. So like it might be one tool in the toolbox, but I just don't think it's a replacement for analysis...
It is not going to necessarily help you figure out what you need to do. The researcher has honed that overtime so not easily replicating it.
As opposed to thinking through the logic of the science and thinking is it credible, that is harder (for ai). Not necessarily more time consuming but harder to outsource to an ai tool.

codes.name: AI Adoption and Organizational Strategy
codes.description: This code covers factors influencing the integration of AI tools within research organizations, including barriers, facilitators, and strategic investment opportunities.
codes.semantic_definition: The organizational dynamics, policies, and strategic considerations involved in the successful or hindered implementation of AI technologies in a research environment.
example_quotes: Most ppl I ask, at RAND there are not as many ppl using it; the few that have say they use it to do what I am doing to help fix code or wordsmith text.

I think we might be a little bit slower [level of adoption], whether that is right I don’t know. I personally feel others are using this and I should… it is speeding things up for ppl in a way that makes me feel I don’t want to be left behind but I feel a little about it.

There could be more along those lines, showcasing how ppl use it successfully. A little bit but not a ton and someone super savvy and using it a lot could give a rundown of how they use it day to day.
I don't know if they're thinking about this, but I'm, I'm sure various alternative survey panels will be providing this like a virtual version of their panel that you can get at any time.

codes.name: Barriers to AI Integration
codes.description: Obstacles that hinder the widespread adoption and effective use of AI tools within a research organization.
codes.semantic_definition: Factors that impede the seamless incorporation of AI technologies into existing research workflows and practices.
example_quotes: I don’t know if ppl feel like they are not supposed to use these bc I know RAND has its own specific rand chat and rand came out and said don’t use something, so part of me wonders if ppl are hesitant for that reason.
I guess if you are coding work that classified.
I think we might be a little bit slower [level of adoption], whether that is right I don’t know.

codes.name: Enablers for AI Adoption
codes.description: Factors and strategies that facilitate and encourage the successful integration and utilization of AI tools within a research organization.
codes.semantic_definition: Conditions, resources, and approaches that promote the effective uptake and application of AI technologies in research.
example_quotes: There could be more along those lines, showcasing how ppl use it successfully.
A little bit but not a ton and someone super savvy and using it a lot could give a rundown of how they use it day to day.
Having ppl using it and sharing. I have a sister who is an attorney and she uses it in ways I would not think of.
Maybe we can create something for sharing.

codes.name: Strategic AI Investments
codes.description: Proposed or actual organizational initiatives and investments aimed at leveraging AI for advanced research capabilities, institutional knowledge management, and operational efficiency.
codes.semantic_definition: Deliberate allocation of resources towards developing or acquiring AI-powered solutions that provide a competitive advantage, enhance internal processes, or create novel research opportunities.
example_quotes: Something that I've been thinking about that would be super helpful if it was possible for researchers is the idea like we have our ALP panels. You know of people and something I was thinking about would be if we could take those panels and almost for like each person develop an AI agent of that person program it with like personality traits...

If there's some way for AI to like, take all of our reports and our recommendations. And Help us to become more situationally aware of things that we've already recommended that might have come out as not being implemented because there's a barrier that prevents that...
It would be really beneficial for a lot of in a lot of ways in a lot of different ways across the project life cycle. So you know, just for the obvious business development.

I said I thought it was odd we don’t use some of the internal budgeting and figuring out where ppl have labor allocated to do labor forecasting. Thinking about how we already have a lot of data there and how we can pull it… to staff projects I’m bidding.

analytic_question: What are the key themes and challenges in using AI for qualitative research?
